channel.title: Adept problem =(
channel.description:
well It just froze in the middle of something and it wouldn't continue, so I closed the session via ctrl +alt + del, and then logged back in, however, when I start adept to try again it says another process is using a certain directory.. How do I actually reset a session, not just pause and resume?[br][size=1]Posted on: April 17, 2007, 09:11:57 PM[/size][hr]I also killed it via terminal, as it seems thru the process table..
kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$ sudo kill adept_manager Password: ERROR: garbage process ID "adept_manager". Usage: kill pid ... Send SIGTERM to every process listed. kill signal pid ... Send a signal to every process listed. kill -s signal pid ... Send a signal to every process listed. kill -l List all signal names. kill -L List all signal names in a nice table. kill -l signal Convert between signal numbers and names. kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$ sudo kill -l adept_manager Signal "adept_manager" not known. kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$ sudo kill pid 19462 ERROR: garbage process ID "pid". Usage: kill pid ... Send SIGTERM to every process listed. kill signal pid ... Send a signal to every process listed. kill -s signal pid ... Send a signal to every process listed. kill -l List all signal names. kill -L List all signal names in a nice table. kill -l signal Convert between signal numbers and names. kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

kloplop321:

I don’t save the sessions, it automatically does, and I want it to stop!

iirc, it’s in the system settings under advanced
also, don’t use adept/synaptic to install jre or jdk, use apt-get

Read full topic

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

I don’t save the sessions, it automatically does, and I want it to stop!

Read full topic

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

one of the reasons i don’t save my sessions

Read full topic

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

but then what else could be accessing it?[br][size=1]Posted on: April 17, 2007, 09:34:05 PM[/size][hr]I found out that it was the sun-java5-jre installation that was paused and had to do sudo apt-get -f install to finish it.

Read full topic

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Then the process isn’t running.

Read full topic

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

there is no default for me. and
“sudo killall adept_manager
adept_manager: no process killed”

nvm, there is a default but it also says (previous) aside it. Which I want a whole new session, the KDE session is the same as default(previous) as it seems.

Read full topic

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

sudo killall adept_manager

But on the login menu just select ‘default’ as the session type.

Read full topic

item.title: Adept problem =(
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

well It just froze in the middle of something and it wouldn’t continue, so I closed the session via ctrl +alt + del, and then logged back in, however, when I start adept to try again it says another process is using a certain directory… How do I actually reset a session, not just pause and resume?[br][size=1]Posted on: April 17, 2007, 09:11:57 PM[/size][hr]I also killed it via terminal, as it seems thru the process table…

kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$ sudo kill adept_manager
Password:
ERROR: garbage process ID “adept_manager”.
Usage:
kill pid … Send SIGTERM to every process listed.
kill signal pid … Send a signal to every process listed.
kill -s signal pid … Send a signal to every process listed.
kill -l List all signal names.
kill -L List all signal names in a nice table.
kill -l signal Convert between signal numbers and names.
kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$ sudo kill -l adept_manager
Signal “adept_manager” not known.
kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$ sudo kill pid 19462
ERROR: garbage process ID “pid”.
Usage:
kill pid … Send SIGTERM to every process listed.
kill signal pid … Send a signal to every process listed.
kill -s signal pid … Send a signal to every process listed.
kill -l List all signal names.
kill -L List all signal names in a nice table.
kill -l signal Convert between signal numbers and names.
kloplop321@kloplop321-desktop:~$

Read full topic
